body:
This PR:
- Makes `vim.pack.add()` work inside 'plugin/' directories (like '~/.config/nvim/plugin/mine.lua') without an explicit `load = true`.
- Makes `vim.pack.add()` immediately react to change in source of an existing plugin: delete immediately and install from the new source. This is mostly a small quality of life improvement, but this avoids having to document this use case as "`vim.pack.del()` + 'change `src` in init.lua' + `:restart`".

    *Note*: This is a part of #34771. There is (currently) no "react to `version` change" because it might conflict with suggested workflow for reverting plugin (see #36131). Might change in the future, but needs discussions.
- Document currently suggested workflow for reverting a plugin after bad update (related to #36131).

comment_regular_data.body:
Regarding documenting a workflow for how to revert from a bad update (to partially address #36131), I realized that merging #36338 behavior of "install immediately all missing plugins with valid lock data" can be used there also.

If requiring Internet connection for reverting from a bad update is acceptable, then the example workflow might be something like this:
- Restore 'nvim-pack-lock.json' to the working state.
- Manually delete plugin directories that were updated.
- Run `:restart`. Lockfile synchronization step will autoinstall missing plugins at the revision from the lockfile.

This is not as clean as a dedicated `vim.pack.restore(lockfile_path)`, but it is definitely less maintenance and code in `vim.pack`.
Rebased on `master` and resolved conflicts after #36468 was merged.
Rebased on `master` and fixed up [an issue after #36573](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36573#discussion_r2532186483)..

> example workflow might be something like this:
> 
> * Restore 'nvim-pack-lock.json' to the working state.
> * Manually delete plugin directories that were updated.
> * Run `:restart`. Lockfile synchronization step will autoinstall missing plugins at the revision from the lockfile.
> 
> This is not as clean as a dedicated `vim.pack.restore(lockfile_path)`

Ideally, we should have `update(lockfile=...)` and it just overwrites the filesystem state (except any cases where HEAD is checked out to a branch?). The "two sources of truth" is not ideal.

I am sure you explained the current tradeoffs somewhere, but I haven't internalized them :)

> The "two sources of truth" is not ideal.

The #36338 makes lockfile be in sync when it comes to 'pack/core/opt' directory and entries on the lockfile.

The revisions of plugins are always in sync with the lockfile, unless user manually changes the revision of the plugin on disk.

I am not really opposed to something like `vim.pack.restore()` (not sure about `vim.pack.update()`; maybe), but it has to accommodate users who don't VCS track their lockfile. Maybe some kind of backup for N previous lockfile state.
